Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Development of a Novel Double-resonance Fiber-laser-induced Fluorescence Instrument for Long-term, High-sensitivity, Interference-free Measurements of Hydroxyl Radical (OH)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project focuses on the development of a novel method for measuring ambient hydroxyl radicals (OH) in the atmosphere, based on the use of infra-red, ultra-violet, laser-induced fluorescence (IR-UV LIF). The project is a collaborate effort with scientists in the laboratory of Professor Dr. Andreas Wahner, Director of the Institute for Energy and Climate Research at Forschungszentrum JÃ¼lich (FZJ) in Germany. Previous fundamental studies on this method have found that it is highly sensitive and free from chemical interferences, but its use has been restricted to physical-chemistry laboratories due to limitations associated with maintaining the stability of the laser in the field. The scientists will explore the coupling of a highly selective spectroscopic method to the latest advances in fiber laser technology for the development of a novel OH LIF instrument.

The hydroxyl radical is the most important oxidizing species in the atmosphere. It reacts with many chemical species in air, oxidizing them and serving as a cleansing mechanism for the ultimate removal of important trace gases such as air pollutants and greenhouse gases. The novel method being developed is expected eventually to be adapted worldwide for field use, enabling long-term measurements of the hydroxyl radical. The resulting data will be critical for improving models of air quality and climate change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Oxidation of compounds in the troposphere controls the formation and of secondary pollutants as well as the degradation of primary emissions, secondary pollutants and some climate active gases, such as methane. Therefore, a quantitative mechanistic understanding of the concentration of the hydroxyl radical, OH, which is the most important tropospheric oxidant, is important. Accurate measurements of OH are crucial to accurately model key chemical processes in the atmosphere, including oxidation of volatile organic compounds. These processes are directly linked to human health and climate impacts via the formation of secondary organic aerosol and tropospheric ozone. Discrepancies continue to exist between measured and modeled OH concentrations, including in regions with high VOC and low nitrogen oxide concentrations. It has been shown that for some of the measurements instrumental interferences exist that can affect the measured OH concentrations. Therefore, it is of great interest to evaluate alternate OH measurement techniques. In this proposal, we leverage advances in laser technology to evaluate a two-laser detection technique, two photo laser-induced fluorescence. The method should not be prone to the interferences observed in the current method, a one photon laser-induced fluorescence method. The results of a theoretical model for the specific lasers used demonstrate good detection limits. The laboratory studies suggest that some of the parameters in the model, based on spectroscopic parameters determined in previous studies, may not be accurate. The final evaluation of the detection limit and characteristics of the two-photon method are currently being finalized.
